title: 111_s3754
content: The Act may be cited as the "Pigford and Individual Indian Money Account Litigation Settlement Act of 2010". Pigford Settlement Agreement is included in the Act. The Department of Agriculture is appropriated $1,150,000,000 for a Settlement Agreement related to Black Farmers Discrimination Litigation. These funds are in addition to $100,000,000 from the Commodity Credit Corporation for Pigford claims. The funds can only be used after the CCC funds are fully obligated and are subject to the terms of the Settlement Agreement. The Settlement Agreement funds must be used as specified, or returned to the Treasury. If the agreement is not executed, only $100,000,000 from the CCC will be available for Pigford claims. No party is required to enter into any settlement agreement, and this section does not create a basis for a Pigford claim. The section clarifies that it does not create a basis for a Pigford claim and makes specific amendments to the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008. The section makes specific amendments to the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 by redesignating subsections and striking certain paragraphs. SEC. 3. THE INDIVIDUAL INDIAN MONEY ACCOUNT LITIGATION SETTLEMENT ACT OF 2010. In this Act, key definitions include Amended Complaint, Land Consolidation Program, Litigation, Plaintiff, and Secretary, all related to the Individual Indian Money Account Litigation Settlement Act of 2010. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. "Settlement" refers to the Class Action Settlement Agreement dated December 7, 2009. The "Side Agreement on Attorneys' Fees, Expenses, and Costs" is an agreement between Class Counsel and Defendants regarding legal fees. The "Trust Administration Class" is defined in the Settlement. The Settlement is authorized, ratified, and confirmed by the court in the District of Columbia, which has jurisdiction over the claims asserted in the Amended Complaint. The court may certify the Trust Administration Class despite the requirements of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. Upon certification, the Trust Administration Class is treated as a class under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(b)(3) for the Settlement. A Trust Land Consolidation Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States upon final approval of the Settlement, providing funds for land consolidation efforts over a 10-year period. Upon final approval of the Settlement, $2,000,000,000 will be deposited in the Trust Land Consolidation Fund from appropriated funds. This aims to conduct the Land Consolidation Program and cover specified costs. The Secretary may transfer up to $60,000,000 from the Trust Land Consolidation Fund to the Indian Education Scholarship Holding Fund upon final approval of the Settlement. The Indian Education Scholarship Holding Fund will be established in the Treasury of the United States. The Secretary can acquire fractional interests in trust or restricted land under the Land Consolidation Program. Unlocatable plaintiffs will be treated accordingly if they cannot be located within 5 years of final approval. Individual Indians who receive amounts under the Settlement through the Land Consolidation Program will not have to include them in gross income or for calculating adjusted gross income under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Individual Indians receiving amounts under the Settlement will not have them counted as income or resources for federal programs for one year. The Court will determine the Plaintiffs' entitlement to Incentive Awards and fees under the Settlement Agreement. The Plaintiffs in the Litigation may be entitled to incentive awards, attorneys' fees, expenses, and costs in accordance with controlling law. Class Counsel's request for attorneys' fees, expenses, and costs will be described in a notice. The Settlement requires disclosure of attorneys' fees, expenses, and costs. The Court has discretion to approve Qualifying Banks for the Settlement funds. The Secretary must consult on Trust Land Consolidation Fund implementation. The Secretary must consult with federally recognized Indian tribes for prioritizing and selecting land tracts for consolidation of fractionated interests under the Settlement. Implementation of paragraph F. of the Settlement will be done through contracts or compacts under the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. Trust Administration Class Adjustments involve deductions from the Accounting/Trust Administration Fund. The Court will set aside $50,000,000 from the Accounting/Trust Administration Fund for equitable adjustments to payments for Trust Administration Class members who demonstrate unfair compensation under the Settlement. The Court has discretion to establish procedures for Trust Administration Class members to receive adjustments. The Court also has discretion in determining whether adjustments should be made and the amount, which is not appealable. Adjustment payments will be distributed after class member payments are made from the Settlement. Any remaining funds from the set-aside amount will be handled accordingly. The Court may appoint a special master to determine equitable adjustments under the Settlement, with any decisions subject to Court review. Additionally, the Secretary will select 2 members for a special board of trustees. The special board of trustees for the Settlement will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with federally recognized Indian tribes. SEC. 4. Use of stimulus funds to offset spending by rescinding unobligated balances from the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 to offset any net increase in spending or foregone revenues. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must report the amounts rescinded to congressional committees.
